urn:contentItem:5S8N-R5W1-JBSN-1002-00000-00Why Wireless Could Get More Complicated2018-05-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:08ZLexisNexisWhy Wireless Could Get More Complicatedby Chris Nolter

T-Mobile US Inc.'s (TMUS) acquisition of Sprint Corp. (S), could have far-reaching implications for many in the world of wireless, if approved.

Comcast Corp. (CMCSA) and big tech companies such as Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) may have to take a closer look at how they fit into a consolidated wireless industry, according to one wireless industry executive. 

Alex Gellman, CEO of wireless infrastructure company Vertical Bridge LLL, said in an interview that a cable operator, satellite TV provider or even a Silicon Valley power could be enticed to enter the wireless business themselves as the mobile carriers merge.

"A lot of the ingredients are in the primordial soup and its waiting for a bolt of lightning to create life," said Gellman, regarding the potential for an outsider to enter the wireless business. 

Cable companies, big tech firms and other ancillary telecoms will need to decide whether they want to buy, invest or partner more closely with a wireless company to stay competitive.

Comcast, for instance, sells wireless through Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) and Charter Communications Inc. (CHTR) is preparing to launch a similar service, which is dubbed a mobile virtual network operator, or MVNO, in wireless industry lingo. A Comcast spokesman said the company's mobile pact with Verizon is "off to a great start" and has added 577,000 subscribers since it's launch in June.

"It's difficult to control your fate and have a profitable business when you're going through an MVNO or a re-seller type structure," Gellman said.

Meanwhile, Dish Network Corp. (DISH) has purchased wireless spectrum over the last decade or so, and has told the Federal Communications Commission that it plans to launch a 5G service. 

Dish has been looking for an investor or partner to build out a network, and the company's wireless ambitions have been the subject of lengthy speculation.

Charlie Ergen's company, alone or with a partner, is the most likely candidate to launch a fourth network given its spectrum holdings, MoffettNathanson LLC analyst Craig Moffett suggested in a report following the Sprint merger announcement.

"Having a wireless industry with three players rather than four would increase the odds that a new fourth player might enter the market," Moffett wrote. Regulators could ask T-Mobile and Sprint to make a concession that would help a new carrier inter the market, the analyst added, which presumably could include divestitures. 

Dish declined to comment, though the topic will surely come up when the company reports earnings next Tuesday.

Mobile networks are increasingly important to Google, Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) and other tech companies that reach more users over mobile devices and even--in the case of Amazon--potentially deliver goods by drones. Google and Amazon did not respond to queries about whether they might look to invest in, partner with or buy wireless operations.

"It's going to create more pressure on these companies that are dependent on wireless access to the customer," Gellman said. "When you have the carrier world consolidating from four to three, that can't be good from their perspective."

Boca Raton, Fla.-based Vertical Bridge has over 61,000 cites through wireless towers or cites placed on rooftops, billboards or other infrastructure. The company's backers include Digital Bridge Holdings LLC, The Jordan Company, Goldman, Sachs & Co.'s (GS) GS Infrastructure Partners and Stonepeak Infrastructure Partners.

Gellman was a former Chief Operating Officer of Global Tower Partners, which sold to American Tower Corp. (AMT) for $4.8 billion in 2013.

Global Tower executives and others formed Vertical Bridge-backer Digital Bridge following the sale. Digital Bridge invests in a range of telecom infrastructure companies, including ExteNet Systems, which designs and operates alternative wireless infrastructure systems; data center operators DataBank  and Vantage Data Centers; as well as infrastructure companies that operate in Columbia, Mexico and Peru.

"We look at this as a real estate business," Gellman said of wireless infrastructure. Vertical Bridge's criteria for acquisitions include ground rights, title rights and whether the property can be mortgaged. Another is the quality of the physical assets, and whether Vertical Bridge can add capacity and tenants.

As carriers launch 5G networks, which connect cars and myriad devices and operate at high speeds, reducing latency will be a major issue. Reducing latency means moving computing and wireless cites closer to users. 

The impact of the Sprint and T-Mobile merger on tower and infrastructure companies is complicated.

"The risk is three bigger carriers more market power more ability to exert any pressure on infrastructure companies, and I think it will drive a desire for infrastructure companies to be bigger themselves," Gellman said.

The timing of the merger closing is a factor, he added. T-Mobile and Sprint plan to decommission 35,000 cell sites, but will add 10,000 as they stitch their networks together. The companies also plan to aggressively invest in 5G networks, which would require infrastructure spending. 

If the 5G investment occurs alongside the decommissioning of sites, it would lessen the pain for wireless carriers. The tower have time to prepare. It would take a year to a year and a half for the merger partners to get approval--which may very well not happen. The deal partners would then have to finalize and implement their network plans.

The current market with four providers had its own issues, Gellman noted.

"From the perspective of the tower and infrastructure industry, it's not a big secret that Sprint hasn't really invested a lot in their network over the last number of years," Gellman said.

"Is it better to have four national competitors than three? Sure," he said. "But one of them wasn't really investing anyway."

urn:contentItem:5F7C-G5V1-JCBJ-K4VM-00000-00Why write? feminism, publishing and the politics of communication;Report2014-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:08ZLexisNexisPg. 99(18)Why write? feminism, publishing and the politics of communicationReportKember, Sarah

  INTRODUCTION: OPEN/CLOSED: RIGHTS, ACCESS AND THE ELISION OF POLITICS        
   The language of openness is powerful and persuasive. (1)        
   John Holmwood      
   The efficacy of the language of openness is dependent in part on the exclusion of a binary opposite, or rather, a sequence of binary opposites: closure, secrecy (versus transparency), darkness (versus light), lies (versus truth) and so on. Open government, for example, is about making power itself transparent, bringing it to truth and light and thereby holding politicians to account without, as it were, any further need for action. Similarly, if open access is merely about getting publicly funded research out from 'behind the paywalls of high-subscription-cost journals' and making it free and available to use and re-use and if copyright reform--including exceptions for parody and quotation--is partly about increasing access then 'What is there to contest?' (CE, p2). For the sociologist John Holmwood contestation is tied to the recognition that open access occurs in the context of enclosure and that 'commercial enclosure is emerging as a significant objective of public policy' (CE, p2).        
   Two key aspects of public policy in the UK are linked by a language of openness that simultaneously excludes and produces commercial enclosure by means of the increased privatisation and marketisation of knowledge and creativity. 

The Finch report on open access, published in 2012, maintains that barriers to access, especially when research is publicly funded 'are increasingly unacceptable in an online world' in as far as they 'restrict the innovation, growth and other benefits' that might accrue. (2) A concern here with public access to publicly funded research by means of 'enhanced transparency, openness and accountability' segues to an emphasis on 'closer linkages between research and innovation, with benefits for public policy and services, and for economic growth' (p5) [my emphasis]). Access here is effectively access to research for private industry or small and medium enterprises. Published a year earlier, the Hargreaves review of Intellectual Property (IP) is also concerned that IP rights that 'support growth by promoting innovation through the offer of a temporary monopoly to creators and inventors' might also 'stifle growth where transaction costs are high or rights are fragmented in a way that makes them hard to access'. (3) If the problem with IP is that it fosters a closed market dominated by established players in technology and content, the solution is to redesign IP in order to facilitate a fairer, more transparent, more open and competitive market that encourages new entrants and enables rather than constrains further innovation. The solution to piracy in a digital world 'where copying and distribution are more or less free', is not, for Hargreaves, copyright enforcement as much as a modernisation of copyright law that encourages 'open and competitive markets in licensed digital content' (p10).      
   The Finch recommendations in favour of 'gold' open access publishing funded by author or article processing charges (APCs) plus minimal restrictions on the rights of use and re-use are in the process of being incorporated into the UK Higher Education sector. (4) The process is uneven and controversial, not least since the Creative Commons license (CC BY) mandated by Research Councils UK (RCUK) allows for commercial re-use of research material with attribution rather than the author's permission. An alternative to this would be a non-commercial share-alike license (CC BY-NC-SA) or one that simply allows non-commercial users to download and share work as long as the author is credited (CC BY-NC-ND). Martin Paul Eve, an advocate of open access, or rather, of the re-politicisation of open access, nevertheless recognises it as an instrument of neoliberalism understood 'as the practice of using the free market as the assignation of all value'. (5) He lists the key traits of neoliberalism as:        
   1. A fixation on quantification and measurement      
   2. The belief that all aspects of society are best handled on a for-profit basis through competition
   3. A nominal insistence on transparency, accountability and openness, so that point 1 can best be achieved.    
   The Research Excellence Framework (REF) will mandate open access publishing in the next assessment round, scheduled for 2020. It fits all three of Eve's key traits of neoliberalism and is an effect, he argues, of the privatisation of knowledge through open access. If this is the case, can open access also be a mechanism for challenging the privatisation of knowledge? For Eve, among others, it can. [6] CC BY licenses might mean that 'yes, people can re-sell your work. However, they cannot stop you from distributing it for free.' Building on an earlier address to these issues in New Formations, (7) it would seem that whatever the potential of what Janneke Adema and Gary Hall refer to as radical or scholar-led open access, there is little doubt that the policy agenda constitutes not only a commercial enclosure of academic research but also an enclosure of knowledge itself. (8) This is especially the case in the arts and humanities where the provision of block grants for APCs is limited, and the ability of academic authors to 'pay-to-say' will be uneven at best. In 'Open Access: HEFCE, REF2020 and the Threat to Academic Freedom', Meera Sabaratnam and Paul Kirby maintain that the gold route to open access threatens academic freedom by placing pressure on institutions to distribute inadequate funding (which they cannot do fairly, openly or transparently) and increases academic inequality 'by linking prestige in research and publishing to the capacity to pay APCs, rather than to academic qualities'. (9) There is a question mark then, not only over who publishes and where but over what is published--the kind of knowledge produced. Work may very well be judged by standards other than peer review.    
   The premise of the Hargreaves recommendations is that the IP framework is out of date and must adapt to new technology:  
   IP law must adapt to change. Digital communications technology involves routine copying of text, images and data, meaning that copyright law has started to act as a regulatory barrier to the creation of certain kinds of new, internet based businesses (IP, p3)
   A progressive, deterministic view of technology is supported here, and in the Finch report by a narrative of crisis and catch-up and by an ontology of the digital as copying, re-use and sharing. If digital technology simply is copying, re-use and sharing then the seemingly uncontestable assertion is that IP law should strive to set it free (where freedom is, of course, a function and condition of the market). The narrative that IP is broken and must therefore be fixed, working alongside the narrative that access is broken and must therefore be fixed, unites the pro-and anti-copyright agendas in a technocratic rational consensus that denies and negates any asymmetry of interest and effectively de-politicises the debate. Responses to Hargreaves' recommendations for the modernisation of copyright and lifting of regulatory barriers that restrict commercial copying demonstrate that the technocratic consensus, the narrative of crisis and catch-up is being narrowed from its address to the digital world in general to the Internet more specifically and finally, to the spectre of Google. As Hargreaves writes:        
   During the Review, conversations about the Google Books Agreement tended to divide people between those who see Google as the likeliest and most efficient reshaper of global markets in digital content, because its business model relies upon connecting online consumers with digital content in all media; and those who point with concern to Google's already very considerable market power, profiting from delivering access to other companies' content, whether provided by legitimate services or not. Google's size and reach in global digital markets has already provoked the attention of EU competition authorities. Google itself may be at a point of recognition that its size requires it to proceed at least to some extent by negotiation and agreement rather than only by bold entrepreneurial strikes which leave courts, regulators and governments gasping to catch up (IP, p36).  
   A more recent report entitled 'Supporting the Creative Economy' is highly critical of the Hargreaves review of IP and of the UK Government's largely favourable response to it. (10) Written by the Department of Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) which supports the creative industries, including publishing, it goes as far as attributing an 'underlying agenda' to IP reforms supported by the Intellectual Property Office which comes under the remit of a separate government department, namely, Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS). This underlying agenda, according to DCMS (versus BIS) is 'driven at least in part by technology companies (Google foremost among them)'. (11) Elsewhere, it refers to 'the perceived power and influence of Google in the Government's inner, policy-making sanctum' implying, therefore, that the Government commissioned Hargreaves review is not as balanced and objective regarding the spectre of Google as it may sound, but rather, as the phrase 'gasping to catch up' might suggest, more envious and/or enchanted. The DCMS report is picked up and promoted by a publisher, Zelijka Marosevic, who refers to 'the concern of many in publishing and in other creative industries that cabinet ministers are holding private meetings and are keen to curry favour with the big tech companies, while they possess too little concern for the creative industries'. (12) Google in particular 'is held to account for its "derisorily ineffective" response to preventing its search from leading users to sites that abuse copyright laws'. Like Google, she concludes, the Government seems less interested in the rights of individuals than those of industry, less interested in publishing than in the tech industry, less interested in enforcing than diluting IP Addressed directly to Google, this Good Old Fashioned 'copy-fight' is more asymmetric and more inevitable than ever. The UK Government is already implementing Hargreaves' recommendations for a Digital Copyright Exchange that does exactly what Google, on account of its monopoly, was not permitted to do, namely, turn 'an unlicensed approach to the mass digitisation of the world's books into what is, in effect, an online licensing system, complete with stakeholder governance and disputes procedures' (IP, p36). Here, in the DCMS approved 'digital market place', the Copyright Hub where licenses are bought and sold, the disputes over copyright are effectively regulated and contained. (13)
   Alongside the deterministic crisis and catch-up narratives narrowed down to the spectre of Google, binaries of open versus closed, publicly versus privately owned content, free versus commercial culture structure the reform of access and IP. In as far as politics is elided by the technocratic consensus that unites pro- and anti-copyright agendas, advocates for commercialisation and those for creative commons, the possibility of re-politicisation emerges in the rejection of such consensus and with what, in a Derridean sense, remains undecidable or incommensurate with respect to the binaries. (14) A paragraph that evokes Derrida so soon after Hargreaves requires, I suspect, a note on method, or rather, the elucidation of a strategy of reading and writing.    
   Deconstruction is a strategy for overturning and intervening in the hierarchical binaries that structure UK policy and Western philosophy alike. Here, following Gary Hall and his agenda for new cultural studies, I resolutely refuse (overturn, corrupt, interrupt) the binary of policy and philosophy, the concrete and the abstract, the political and the (merely) theoretical that has become, if anything, yet more hierarchical in the decades following deconstruction and 'after' theory. (15) The always more than philosophical, abstract and theoretical point of deconstruction, its 'strategic intent' is first to invert and then to corrupt binaries (noting, of course, that all attempts at inversion and corruption are captured in part by what they seek to overturn) and to present new, provisional concepts without ever offering them as a third term or a means of resolving a dichotomy. (16) Deconstruction is more of a movement than a method, a movement of overturning 'in such a way as to register the constitutive dependence of the major on the minor term' and also a 'movement beyond the framework delimited by these terms'. (17) The new provisional concepts that move beyond frameworks by temporarily suspending them connect feminism with deconstruction, Donna Haraway with Jacques Derrida, 'natureculture' and 'FemaleMan' with 'differance' and 'hymen'. (18) They testify that texts matter, are 'material-semiotic' or world building and that criticism is not negative or positive (anti- or pro-) but precisely, political. If power operates through stabilising terms--'the language of openness is powerful and persuasive'--then politics is what is made possible by destabilising them. (19)    
   The de-stabilisation and politicisation of the language of openness is effected in part by recognising its constitutive dependence on commercial enclosure and on the enclosure of criticism itself. If the debate on copyright circling between pro- and anti- Hargreaves, BIS and DCMS, the tech industries aka Google and publishing--encloses critique (as the possibility of politics), the debate on access threatens to enclose academic research and writing and therefore the very conditions of possibility of critique (the conditions of possibility that make politics possible). Work that has already been done on 'the limits of openness'and the opacity of secrecy and transparency is consistent with a deconstructive movement that nevertheless does not realise its full strategic intent without the invention of terms that signal a move beyond. (20) Such terms are the product of writing, of inventiveness through writing and they are hard to find in a post-theoretical, post-deconstructive academic culture embedded in the neoliberalism of which it speaks and reoriented to the presencing of privileged speech acts. If the term phallogocentrism is one that signals a movement beyond the division of speech and writing, presence and absence, fact and fiction, by revealing the constitutive dependence of the masculine major on the feminine minor, then it continues to exist as a significant trace in the contemporary speech-writing system of humanities research: 'The trace does not appear as such, but the logic of its path in a text can be mimed by a deconstructive intervention and hence brought to the fore' (JD).    
   Taking, as my text, the policy and philosophy of copyright and access reform, what are the traces and ruptures that can be mimed and brought to the fore by a deconstructive intervention? It should be noted that such an intervention is premised on the impossibility of interpretation, on an encounter or contact with the text that is neither faithful nor transgressive but rather, inevitably inventive. It should also be noted that the primary mechanism for deconstruction is writing: 'The process of writing always reveals that which has been suppressed, covers over that which has been disclosed, and more generally breaches the very oppositions that are thought to sustain it' (JD). Derrida's writing, 'arche-writing' is a process, happening less on the page (as literal inscription) and more in the movement between what is intended and what is conveyed. (21) This same movement, the archetypal breach in meaning expressed in the neologism 'differance', is evoked by Haraway who reinvents the idea of meaning as differance and sees writing as a means of making a difference. After arche-writing, cyborg writing 'has a special significance for all colonized groups'. It is a mechanism 'of seizing the tools to mark the world that marked them as other'. (22) The tools that writing seizes 'are often stories, retold stories, versions that reverse and displace the hierarchical dualisms of naturalized entities' (p175). My question about traces and ruptures in the con/texts of reform was addressed to a small group of once new, and would-be independent publishers who might regard themselves as colonised in that sense but who have consciously seized the tools to mark the world that marked them and/or others as other. I would not describe them as interviewees but as co-discussants and fellow storytellers. My co-discussants were: Janneke Adema (researcher and blogger on open access publishing), Pauline van Mourik Broekman (Mute), Mercedes Bunz (the Hybrid Publishing Lab), Joe Deville (Mattering Press), Carol Stabile (Ada. A Journal of Gender, New Media & Technology), Eva Weinmayr and Andrea Francke (and publishing). On the basis of my involvement in setting up the Goldsmiths Press, as well as my involvement in the CREATe consortium, I convened and contributed to a discussion that was organised around a number of questions and responses (spoken and written) the first of which had to do with miming traces about copyright and open access. (23)
   CRISIS, WHAT CRISIS? THE FUTURE OF (ACADEMIC) PUBLISHING (AND THE HUMANITIES)
    The UK policy environment (with respect to publishing and other
    so-called creative industries) is currently dominated by the reform          
    of copyright and access. To what extent should issues of ownership        
    and access dominate the debate on publishing? What, if anything, do          
    they occlude? (24)
   For Janneke Adema and Joe Deville in particular, the question of access 'or better said the lack of access' remains important. There is, for Adema, the simple, unacceptable fact of lack of public access to publicly funded research plus the limited distribution of publicly funded research to the increasingly underfunded libraries of Western, as well as non-Western universities. More than that, as Deville puts it, the question of access 'also becomes, access to what? Just academic work? Or the frameworks that produce that work?' Adema argues that:          
    we need to be wary when access, like in the Finch report, becomes        
    dominated by access to business, to stimulate the knowledge economy          
    etc., instead of stimulating creativity and invention, and    
    promoting rethinking, reperforming and deconstructing the way we          
    conduct and publish our research.        
   If access means access to publicly funded research for private industry and the market, it also means limited or lack of access to already marketised research: 'We increasingly don't have access to qualitative specialised research, as this needs to have a certain market-appeal in the current publishing ecology before it is deemed publishable'. (25)    
   If there is a degree of consensus, within the discussion group, that improving access is necessary 'on both sides' or with respect to the production as well as consumption of research, there is also a general agreement that this might not be the first or only priority and that it is useful to think in terms of what isn't currently being thought, said and done about publishing. For Janneke Adema, Joe Deville and Andrea Francke, one of the major occlusions in the debate on access and copyright reform is the question of responsibility. Deville refers to the 'distributed responsibilities' that include academic writers and publishers but also academic institutions, research centres and government. While Mercedes Bunz and Pauline van Mourik Broekman emphasise the absence, or rather 'endless deferral of responsibility'--from government to research centres to academic institutions--when it comes to the allocation of inadequate funds for open access journal publishing, Francke and Adema are interested in how the question of responsibility can be 'mimed' from the con/texts of access and copyright:        
    In the open access movement, and as part of the main open access          
    definitions, access has always gone hand in hand with reuse rights,          
    and this is where the question of copyright comes in. As far as I        
    am concerned, moral rights, i.e. attribution, is all we need in
    academia (and we might rethink this too, who do we attribute  
    exactly), and we should be able to do without copyright in this
    respect. But ownership of a text is a more difficult question,
    because this implies amongst others taking responsibility for a
    text and for the integrity or fixity of the contents that we are          
    publishing. A more interesting question is thus, in what sense are        
    we responsible for our texts? And for what parts or versions of it?          
    Should we only have moral rights or responsibility for specific
    incarnations of our research? In this respect the question of  
    ownership is a broader question than that of copyright I think
    (which for me still functions too much as part of a liberal regime        
    based on property and proprietary objects), as this asks us    
    questions about our responsibility towards texts too.          
   So access has implications for copyright and copyright raises questions about moral rights which give way, for Adema, to a broader question of ownership as responsibility for research that is not just versioned but fluid in excess of proprietary objects. For her, and for Carol Stabile, neoliberalism institutes an overinvestment in the object, the book or article that is the end result of publishing. Concerned (only) with access to, or rights associated with such objects, a neoliberal rationale assumes and implies, as Stabile puts it, that everything is fine 'below the line'. What lies below the line are the institutional and extra-institutional 'life conditions' (van Mourik Broekman) that structure the research and writing process as well as specific scholarly practices such as peer review and citation that are, in Stabile's words, 'biased and broken'. Underlying this, below the line that is below the line of accessible, attributable or copyrighted objects is the double enclosure (commercial and critical) of published and publishable output in the humanities in particular.          
   With US academics Mark Garrett Cooper and John Marx, I am wary of reading even a double enclosure as a crisis in the humanities, preferring instead to recognise the genealogy of crisis that is, in effect, no crisis at all, but rather an ongoing, dynamic and antagonistic encounter with all that is considered to be external to the humanities--digitisation and marketisation included. (26) As Cooper and Marx argue, a crisis model of the humanities tends to fix it in an imaginary golden era in which its core values may be deemed to be under attack from the 'twin pressures of media change and neoliberal policies' (CCC, p140). What is more, 'in this narrative, the humanities becomes the last outpost within the university willing to fight the good fight against economic instrumentality and its technological fetishes (for example, MOOCS)' (p140). As much as I admire her exposure of economic instrumentality and especially its technological fetishes (MOOCS, ebooks, apps, podcasts and so on) in debates on the future of academic publishing, Johanna Drucker does seem to regard humanities scholarship as a last outpost, a stand against academic capitalism that may well be our last. (27) Scholarship, essentialised as being 'hard', 'serious', 'life-long' and the sole preserve of experts and professionals is installed at the 'centre of knowledge production' and all the 'hype around digital alternatives to print sometimes seems like a distraction to blind us from the need to address that reality, as if it will take care of itself if we just find enough apps and devices and platforms to play with' (PD). By suggesting that scholarship, as the presumably unchanging but vulnerable system supporting humanistic knowledge 'is at risk', Drucker shifts the crisis model from publishing per se to the humanities and brings with it a temporality that is not dynamic and antagonistic as much as static and oppositional. The crisis model is the model of binary opposites, of print and digital, of past (scholarship) and present (just so much 'pixel dust'). Deconstructing the crisis model of publishing and of the humanities is, I suggest, a prerequisite to any intervention below the line. Doing it is not easy, since it includes recognising what is at once vital and instrumental about scholarship and arguing, again with Cooper and Marx, that experimentation is not something we might add to, or even recover from within the humanities, but rather something that was always already part of its institutionalisation:
   Crisis-obsessed humanists characteristically fail to appreciate the extent to which institutionalisation and experimentation are interlinked. Innovative collaborations across departments and outside academe's halls disappear in tales that privilege disciplinary formation and defense. Seen in a broader perspective, however, experiment looks just as important as institutionalisation. Collaboration that bridges sometimes antagonistic institutions like the university and the Hollywood studio lacks the certainty of disciplinary defense, while the term innovation smacks of the very corporate rhetoric PhD programs teach humanities scholars to abjure. Nonetheless, generating new ways to engage interlocutors outside the humanities and outside academe has long been a vital part of humanities practice (CCC, p131).        
   What they describe as a 'century-long drama' of institutionalisation and experimentation 'challenges us to reconsider' what institutions and disciplines do (p131) and, rather than seeking to preserve a fixed idea of scholarship (or, as Kathleen Fitzpatrick does, of the scholarly community), it challenges us to attend to the cuts and stabilisations that render scholarship more or less instrumental. (28) A feminist deconstruction of the crisis model--one that is anticipated in Marilyn Strathern's Audit Cultures, Roger Burrow's 'Living with the h-index? Metric assemblages in the contemporary academy' and especially Ros Gill's examination of 'the hidden injuries of the neoliberal university' --is further attuned to the differentiated structure of instrumentalism (and non-instrumentalism) and to the conditions of (im)possibility for a feminist politics of communication. (29)          
   FEMINISM AND SCHOLARLY PRACTICE
    A task for the Humanities would be to rethink not just the 'human'        
    but everything connected with it not, as hitherto, strictly from          
    the perspective of the universal, the concept, but from that of the          
    exception; which is to say, from the perspective of what refuses to          
    fit in, what resists assimilation, but what, in so doing, reveals        
    the enabling limits of all system, synthesis and self-containment.        
    'When one does this', Constantin remarks, 'a new order of rank
    results and the poor exception ... like the girl spurned by the
    stepmother in the fairy tale, enjoys favour and honour'. (30)  
   Scholar-led rather than policy-driven open access is problematic not because it fails to deconstruct the binary of open and closed or, necessarily, because it fails to open out from this binary to consider the politics of scholarly communication. It is problematic, for me in as far as it does this mainly from the perspective of the universal, the concept, and not from that of the exception (Haraway's 'colonized'). This is the reason why my discussion was oriented toward feminist publishers. When they, or rather, we, albeit as a heterogeneous group, speak of rethinking (once more) text, author and authority or access, rights and responsibility we are already invested in generating a new order of rank, arising from the exception.      
   Hidden labour is a key exception in publishing. Joe Deville refers to its 'unseen others' and asks: 'Do we need to connect OA [open access] publishing to what Susan Leigh Starr calls the 'sociology of the invisible'?' (31) For Mercedes Bunz, a sociology of the invisible would incorporate 'infrastructure work', the work of accounting for, and literally crediting everybody involved in producing a book. Through the Hybrid Publishing Lab, Bunz 'is experimenting with an extended edition notice in the beginning of books similar to the closing notes of a movie, which would name the participants engaged in processing the manuscript'. (32) Both she and Deville, when asked why they became involved in publishing initiatives, refer to an investment in collaborative projects and in visibly collective and mutually supportive authorship facilitated by open, peer-to-peer as opposed to double-blind peer review. (33) Deville and his fellow editors at Mattering Press are early career researchers who felt 'that some of the ways in which academic value [was] conferred (e.g. via double-blind peer review) didn't map onto how we were engaging with each other (e.g. more open, supportive, but still feeling [that the] possibility for productive, helpful critique was there)'. If early career researchers are also a key exception in publishing, it is because they constitute much of the hidden labour behind the double-blind peer review process that is doubly precarious for them, that affects them asymmetrically both as reviewers--engaged in casual, temporary employment or facing the hurdles of promotion and tenure--and as the reviewed--seeking constructive criticism but vulnerable to something more judgmental. Martin Paul Eve, as an advocate of scholar-led open access, does recognise this exception. In his outline of the problems with peer review he asks:  
    whether it is right that a mere two academics, in most instances,        
    although sometimes only one, have the private, unaccountable, final          
    word on an article's acceptability. For Early Career Researchers          
    (ECRs) this private decision can be the difference between a  
    lifetime of employment in academia or a lengthy period of      
    re-training. (34)  
   My colleagues at Mattering Press (and elsewhere) might even consider themselves poised between, facing the prospect of combining a lifetime of employment in academia and a lengthy period of retraining as publishers. It is significant that they cite their experience of peer review as one of the factors that led them to this prospect. As Rosalind Gill states, a bad experience of peer review up to and including the rejection of an article can lead some early career academics to conclude 'that they really aren't good enough' and should not go on, where others are driven 'to work even harder' (BS, p240).          
   For the most part, Eve's critique of peer review is generic and dispassionate. His primary concern is to defend open access from the accusation that it abandons peer review as a form of quality control and to suggest instead that openness provides an opportunity to rethink peer review in relation to 'community' in particular. For a sense of how, for example, 'anonymity can be problematic' and for a sense of the unevenly distributed cost of substituting constructive feedback for harsh judgment, it is necessary to adopt a different perspective (BS, p75). In her feminist reflection on scholarly practice, Gill engages with early career researchers and argues that 'the hidden injuries of the neoliberal university' are experiential (affective, embodied and internalised) and differentiated according to gender, race and class (p240). By means of some 'unscientific' data and conversations held through (what she refers to as) improper channels of communication (emails, memos, letters and other 'fragments') she offers a powerful, impassioned account of the problem with anonymity and the cost of 'gratuitous attack and cruelty' (pp231, 229). One of her concerns is to challenge double-blind peer review by ending the silence about how it is experienced--and by whom. She reports what was said to her by a female friend: 'I'm really fed up. I heard yesterday that my article for x journal was turned down ... one of the referee's comments was vile ... When I read it it was like a slap in the face ...' (p228).          
   A less experiential, more experimental or theoretical approach might relate the problem of anonymity to the problem of knowledge and specifically to what Haraway refers to as disembodied knowledge (SCW). (35) Disembodied knowledge is transcendent, detached from the knower and therefore from responsibility and accountability. If this is mainstream, masculinist knowledge for Haraway, then feminist knowledge is situated, not detached but attached to an embodied knower who is therefore accountable for what she produces. Open, or community-based peer-to-peer review that the feminist open access (non-APC) journal Ada already practices might, as Carol Stabile suggests, be more 'situated, accountable and dialogic' but it is also very time consuming and labour intensive. We discussed how to account for this labour intensiveness when the differentiated 'intensivity' and 'extensivity' of academic labour is part of what this and other feminist publishing projects are attempting to address (BS, p231). For Stabile, the intensification and extensification of labour draws on 'love', 'devotion', 'passion' and 'commitment'. Here affect may be self-regulatory and governmental but, for Stabile, it is simply how political work, including feminist publishing, gets done. If we want more open or transparent peer-to-peer review, we have to acknowledge its own closures and secrecies and also 'work even harder (BS, p240; OA).
   FEMINISM AS SCHOLARLY PRAXIS  
   If feminist publishing is caught in the self-regulatory cycle of labour about which it speaks (and writes) then what difference is it making--what kind of difference can it make? In as far as it is the exception in publishing, how does feminist publishing refuse to fit in or to resist assimilation?        
   Working harder here, unworking there      
   In an article on comics and copyright (produced in the form of a comic), Ronan Deazley and Jason Mathis reveal the value of academic labour to the journal publishing industry. (36) Of an annual revenue, in 2007, of over 4 billion[pounds sterling], 1.9 billion[pounds sterling] is the estimated contribution from peer review. In the same year, the cost to funders and researchers of producing original research is estimated at 115 billion [pounds sterling].

   It may not be too much to ask that publishers implement copyright exceptions, but for Deazley and Mathis, it is unlikely to happen: 'it will make no difference to an academic that the copyright regime enables quotation from a work for purposes such as criticism and review, if the publisher chooses not to avail of that exception' (WCC, p24). At this point in their comic, they change register 'from critique to manifesto' (WCC, p28) and, as part of a thought experiment, wonder what would happen if academics decided to act against copyright demands 'imposed upon authors by academic publishers, often without any real need' (WCC, p28). There is, they suggest, a 'beguilingly simple but powerful option: withdraw content and expertise'. This might 'focus the minds of academic publishers' but 'who would do such a thing?'. As a legal academic, Deazley considers it unlikely that legal academics, as a large heterogeneous group with many journal outlets at their disposal, would mobilise with sufficient disinterest and unanimity. So what about feminist academics?  
   In her article on the increase in feminised--flexible, caring, multitasking, relationship-building--affective labour in 'an entrepreneurialized post-crash economy', Carol Stabile returns to Valerie Solanas's SCUM manifesto based on a '(science)fictional organization' for, amongst other things, orchestrated unwork. (37) When you are 'working like a dog', unwork, including the withdrawal of content and expertise, has strategic-anarchic appeal. (38) Another option is not (just) to withdraw but redirect both content and expertise toward publishing outlets that are more ethical, more creatively and intellectually vital, less exploitative and over which academics and other contributors have a greater degree of control. All of the discussants that came together to debate the future of feminism, writing and publishing at Goldsmiths, myself included, are redirecting labour in this way. Some of us are also in the process of withdrawing at least our expertise from mainstreamjournals. (39) As a mixed group of academics and artists, we are all aware that the strategic redeployment of reviewing, editing, reading and writing, as well as the harder work of publishing itself is a form of activism with a history, or rather, a set of histories relating to university presses, artists' books (PNB) and feminist publishing initiatives. (40) It is, of course, no coincidence, and certainly not a facet of digital technological agency per se, that a number of new digital first university presses are in train, that scholars and artists are concerned with the legacy of the artist's book or that feminists are reappraising pamphlets, manifestos and other experimental modes of communication. These are among the ways in which the enclosure of the conditions of possibility of critique (the conditions of possibility that make politics possible) is being acted on. What interests me in particular is the extent to which these separate legacies overlap, and in doing so offer to teach us 'how to dream outside the boundaries of a capitalist matriarchy' manifested as feminised rather than feminist labour (MV).      
   Opening out from openness      
   Joe Deville describes Mattering Press as a material and political intervention, 'very closely aligned with feminist attention to making a difference'. It foregrounds a feminist, not feminised ethics of care, oriented toward the publishing process (the process of producing knowledge differently), its relations and infrastructure. Mattering Press aims to make a difference by 'attending to who and what we become involved with' when we publish, and by 'taking care of not just the human relations we instantiate, but also the material (e.g. payment, production and reviewing models, the printed texts themselves, the digital texts, how these circulate, the work involved in making them circulate)'. All of these things matter in the double sense of being significant and of coming in to being, of materialising as subjects and objects of care. Mattering Press enacts thinking about posthuman agency predicated on relational processes that cut into and across the boundaries of human and non-human entities. Apart from caring more about the entities involved in publishing (authors, readers, texts, payment models), the press is ethical in as far as it strives to make 'better cuts' (LANM) and to enact relations that are responsible and accountable. It takes responsibility not just for the knowledge it produces but also for the way it produces it. It opens out (from) open access in this way, as well as by taking the perspective of the exception.        
   There is a difference, for me, between opening out open access and opening out from open access. I would base this on what I perceive to be a totalising tendency in scholar-led open access, one that will always re-enclose it and that attempts to assimilate, for example, ethics and experimentation to its own cause, namely, the cause of keeping open access open to the outside, to its constitutive relations, processes, texts, materialities, modes and disciplinary contexts. In recognition of this tendency, and drawing on Weber's use of Kierkegaard, Janneke Adema returns open access to a deconstructing movement that foregrounds not the movement (called open access) but movement itself, not relations but relating, not experimentation but experimenting. (41) The difference is in the present participle: 'For the present participle involves a movement that is first of all, repetitive, second of all, never conclusive or contained, third, on-going and futural, and fourth and finally, actual and immediate'. (42) The present participle, for Weber, 'moves in quite a different, more transitional way' to deconstruct 'the model of all knowledge' including scientific, humanistic, academic and artistic knowledge that is 'based on the past participle'. There is no openness in open access that isn't already a form of enclosure. There is, at best, an opening that foregrounds itself and is without cause. Rather than adhere to movements, we should perhaps attend to where movement is. I am intrigued, in this case, by what Pauline van Mourik Broekman has observed in the movement (one towards the other) of artistic and academic research:  
    It is striking that there has been a rash of conferences,      
    exhibitions, workshops in the contemporary art context asking what        
    knowledge and its limits are, but sort of on the understanding that          
    art should be 'let in' to help define it (i.e. it wants to be  
    legitimised, gain access to the domain of 'knowledge'--and via
    artistic research we must read this as academe). Whereas,      
    conversely, one gets the sense that academe is seeking to      
    escape/get out/exit; find new languages, new spaces and platforms,        
    for 'knowledge'. Where do these two tendencies meet?
   Instituting invitalism        
   If there is a degree of movement between art and academia, I'm interested in the extent to which they meet, or might meet through writing. Put another way, how and where is it possible to write out (of), as well as about the hierarchical binaries of openness and the vicious circles of feminised labour? Artists Andrea Franke and Eva Weinmayr of and publishing talk about their Piracy Project as an intellectual property event that tries to avoid 'the black and white approach of yes or no, when it comes to copyright or open culture advocates'. (43) What began as an occupation of an art school library that was under threat of closure has grown into a collection of more than a hundred 'modified, appropriated and copied books from all over the world' including, for example, Whais off piejing (2011), a self-published reversioning of John Berger's Ways of Seeing 'rewritten as if transcribed phonetically from reading by a German or possibly a Finn, creating what looks like a nonsensical new language on the page'. (44)      
   Paul Goldsmith's International Copyright: Principles, Law and Practice is a physical book consisting of screen captures from Google Books. Part of what is captured here 'are the limits Google places on previewing pages, with the (nearly) blank pages stating 'not shown in this preview', taking up most of the book'. (45) Facilitated by labour intensive independent publishing houses engaged in 'everything from experimental writing to republishing out of print or censored material', the collection experiments with copyright and access in order to stimulate debate and encourage further intervention. (46) In addition to the Piracy Project, and publishing have issued a public invitation to 'help us explore the language of piracy'. (47) They offer a list of synonyms for piracy--including 'borrowing, poaching, plagiarizing ... repeating, cloning, translating'--and invite the reader to join them in exploring 'the blurred spaces between these terms'. How, for example, 'does plagiarizing challenge the common perceptions of originality?' By sponsoring one of the terms, the reader contributes to a book chapter that will be written by a scholar or artist and in which they will be credited. They engage in a deconstructive movement that includes new definitions and at least the possibility of new, provisional concepts. As well as the piracy and keywords projects, Eva Weinmayr was involved in a digital real-time collaborative scriptwriting project that was a dialogue 'in the sense that a dialogue creates something bigger in-between us'. Written by 'a journalist, a writer and me', all in different countries, it was, she says, 'an exceptional and rich experience triggering imagination and ideas'. Finally, she asks, 'what would happen if such a method would be used for academic writing?' My own question borrows from hers, linking a method, based on real-time collaborative writing, back to the movement she identifies with Deleuze, the 'thing that flows' between us: 'what would happen if such a movement would be used for academic writing?' Or, going back to Derrida and Haraway, 'what would happen if academic writing became, as it always has been, an art of invention as well as an act of intervention?'
   My own keywords list, translated from and's would consist of antonyms rather than synonyms. A number of them have already been mentioned in this article, including open and closed, experimental and institutional, vital and instrumental. These are the hierarchical binaries that I have, to an extent, deconstructed, falling short, as most academic writers do, of inventing an in-between or alternative term. However, since academic writing, or the configuration of writing, publishing, privatisation and marketisation is, to paraphrase Haraway, the nexus of trouble that I am staying with, and in the spirit of feminist deconstructionism, here is one such term: invitalism. Invitalism is akin to the opportunism of scholar-led open access, the sense that a debate (if not a movement for reform) is open enough to be hacked, hijacked and redirected. Invitalism is antagonistic to the enclosure of openness (including by openness itself), experimentation and especially vitalism. It moves against this enclosure although it does not, in any final sense, achieve it. It is political only in its antagonism and does not in itself constitute an intellectual or creative movement (or indeed, a combination of the two (48)). Invitalism differs from opportunism because it is less confined to a movement and more inclined to wander, for example, between movements for open access and copyright reform. Here (in its wandering) it is attuned to the differentiated structure of instrumentalism and its opposite and to the conditions of (im)possibility for a feminist politics of communication. This politics is neither negative nor affirmative but, rather, strategic. (49) It is always on the move as a politics of intervention (in a text, a system, a movement [including its own], a status quo) and of invention. It takes the incursive move from scholar-led open access and turns it into an invitation. This invitation is issued to academics and artists alike. It is an invitation to unwork the work of writing about scholarly practice and to work harder at the work of writing out of its enclosures. Invitalism is scholarly writing that is not about, but out (as in, half way out) of scholarship, always in the process of reinventing it--of experimenting and institutionalising. Invitalism is invitalising. The difference is in the present participle.
   CONCLUSION: WHY WRITE?        
    In the words of Ed McCabe: 'creativity is one of the last remaining          
    legal ways of gaining an unfair advantage over the competition'.          
 
    IPRs (the major rights being patents, copyright, design rights, and          
    trade marks) incentivise innovation through the offer of a    
    time-limited return on innovative investment. This reduces the risk          
    in inventing and creating new products, so stimulating innovation,        
    competition and stronger economic growth. (50)      
   I have argued that philosophy can reinstate critique and create an opening for political intervention in policies that privatise knowledge and market creativity. Writing is central to a deconstructive philosophy that moves against metaphysics, including the metaphysics of writing expressed in the question: 'what is writing?' Following Heidegger, Derrida critiques the metaphysics of presence, the privileging of 'that which is, or that which appears', reminding us to pay attention 'to the conditions for that appearance'. (JD) The conditions for appearance that I have attended to here include publishing and/as scholarly practice. My main contention that we should write out (as in, write out of), not so much about the differentiated instrumentalisation of scholarly practice (if not transcending then transforming it) presumes to answer a question that is in need of asking. I posed a loaded question to my co-discussants, asking them 'to revisit the association between feminism and writing, to ask again: why write?'      
   Through her long association with Derrida, I invoked Helene Cixous' invocation, her injunction to write:      
    Write, let no one hold you back, let nothing stop you: not man; not          
    the imbecilic capitalist machinery, in which publishing houses are        
    the crafty, obsequious relayers of imperatives handed down by an          
    economy that works against us and off our backs; and not yourself.        
    Smug-faced readers, managing editors, and big bosses don't like the          
    true texts of women female-sexed tests. That kind scares them. (51)          
   Together with Xaviere Gauthier's withering reference to 'the frightful masculine fashion of speaking' that always surprises her ('speaking in order to be right--how ridiculous!' LM, p200), I invoked a feminism that would scare and ridicule the rightness of rights, the assertion, more political than legal that I/we write in the spirit of innovation rather than intervention and in order to secure our 'time-limited return' rather than give vent to a desire that is encultured and embodied. (52) In as far as my own oppositionalism is problematic and returns and desires cannot be separated any more than they can be assimilated, one to the other, then the task of challenging (the instrumentalisation of writing) is more challenging and more provisional. It is, as my Goldsmiths colleagues Terry Rosenberg and Duncan Fairfax argue, the challenge of moving toward 'a form of writing that ... creates a new space from which to write'. (53)
   This form of writing is not experimental but experimenting. For Janneke Adema it includes 'breaking down barriers between formal and informal publications' such as the monograph and the manifesto, the article and the comic. One of the things I appreciate about Kathleen Fitzpatrick's reflections on academic writing is her willingness to be self-reflexive. Referring to anxieties about writing, linked to 'originality, creativity, productivity, ownership and so on', she recognises that she is 'subject to precisely the same concerns and emotions about which I've been writing' and explores ways in which we might be 'less anxious' about our work (PO, pp 51,56). For me, however, the challenge is less about self-reflexivity, less about academics writing about academic writing and more about returning our anxiety to a more externalised desire that is, following Cixous, following Derrida the feminist minor to the masculinist major term of the return.

B5Why Yahoo may pay no taxesU.S. rules for employee stock options and restricted stock benefit big tech firmsJESSE DRUCKER

Many of the biggest and most profitable U.S. technology companies, including Yahoo Inc. and Google Inc., pay little or no corporate income tax, according to an analysis of recently filed annual reports.

Yet the low tax rates - which stem largely from favourable corporate tax treatment long given to employee stock options and restricted stock - aren't clearly shown in financial statements filed to shareholders, which often indicate the companies pay far greater sums to tax authorities.

The companies aren't doing anything wrong. The issue stems partly from an accounting oddity that wasn't fully addressed in the overhaul of stock-options accounting that took effect last year.

Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Yahoo, for example, said in its annual 10-K report filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in February that its "provision for income taxes" last year was 42 per cent of its $1.1-billion (U.S.) in pretax profit. But Yahoo likely won't end up owing any income taxes from last year's profit, according to an analysis by The Wall Street Journal.

The U.S. government isn't losing much, if anything, because of the option-related tax benefits enjoyed by these growing companies. Employees who exercise stock options must include the gains as income they report to the tax authorities. To a large degree, the tax burden is simply shifted from companies to executives and other employees. But the government still may lose out because some individuals owe taxes at rates lower than the 35-per-cent statutory rate applied to big companies.

Still, the gap between some companies' reported and actual tax rates indicates that stock-option accounting can confuse investors. The discrepancy also raises some awkward questions, including whether the revamping of stock-options accounting practices went far enough, and whether shareholders are being given meaningful information about the true profitability of companies that issue lots of options.

The amount shown as a tax expense on some companies' financial statements includes a large portion related to options that "is never ever going to be paid; it's not an expense by any stretch of the imagination," says Albert Meyer, a former accounting professor and now president of Bastiat Capital, a Dallas investment-advisory firm. "I cannot find in accounting theory any reason for it - other than it fulfills the function of creating the impression these companies are paying their taxes."

A Yahoo spokeswoman said the company provides investors tax information in its annual report, and gives additional information about cash paid to the government for taxes in its quarterly earnings calls.

The recently filed annual reports covering 2006 results are the first disclosed since the new rules took effect, and indicate the tax gap owing to benefits from stock-based pay options is still sizable for some companies.

Stock options, a popular form of compensation for many companies, give employees the right to buy shares stock at a preset "strike" price. For years, accounting regulators treated options as though they were essentially free, permitting companies to dole them out liberally, generally with no hit to their bottom lines - and to get a tax deduction in the process. That changed in the United States last year, when new rules forced companies to estimate the long-term value of an option, and to deduct that amount from its income in its financial reporting over the period the options become exercisable.

But when it comes to tax returns, for most options a company has to wait until the option actually is exercised by the employee - often years later - at which point it deducts the difference between the exercise price and the current stock price. For example, if an employee exercises the option with a strike price of $40, and the stock is trading at $60, the company deducts $20 from its return.

In their annual 10-K reports, companies disclose a "tax provision," which in theory is the amount they accrue to pay expected tax bills. But because of the accounting quirk, companies include an amount they never actually pay - the tax-return benefit they receive from options exercised by their employees. The result for big issuers of options with rising share prices is a tax provision that can overstate the company's true tax obligation.

For instance, in a news release announcing 2006 earnings, Mountain View, Calif.-based Google said it had an "effective tax rate" of 23 per cent. But Google's soaring stock price helped generate a $611-million tax benefit from restricted stock that vested as well as options exercised last year - which cut its actual effective tax rate to about 8.8 per cent, according to a Journal estimate.

The problem with this discrepancy, critics say, is that shareholders may not be getting information about Google's true profitability. Is the tech giant even more profitable than it might seem, because it owes less in taxes than its income statement would indicate?

Or is it less profitable, because Google is giving away much of its income to its own employees in the form of stock-option gains that aren't fully reflected on its income statement? Google declined to comment.

The Journal calculated adjusted effective tax rates by subtracting the tax benefit related to stock-based pay from a company's tax provision.

While that benefit is presented in a company's statement of cash flows, and sometimes in its tax footnotes, it generally isn't clear that it effectively reduces the company's reported taxes.

The Journal methodology, reviewed by three accounting experts, can lead to results that are different from the actual cash taxes paid by a company in a given year for several reasons, including the effect of reserves and payments related to previous tax years.

Stock options aren't the only things driving companies' true tax rates below the statutory 35-per-cent U.S. rate.

Some tech firms are still able to take advantage of losses from previous years to credit against taxes on future profit.

And many companies attribute earnings to subsidiaries in countries with lower tax rates.

urn:contentItem:5T8C-GVF1-JBSS-S0SK-00000-00Why you might have to give up your memes2018-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:08ZLexisNexisWhy you might have to give up your memesBy Andre Spicer(CNN)

Editor's note: Andre Spicer is a professor of organizational behavior at Cass Business School, City, University of London. He and Carl Cederstrom are co-authors of "The Wellness Syndrome" and "Desperately Seeking Self-Improvement." The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the author. View more opinion articles on CNN.

(CNN) -- It's the end of the internet as we know it. At least that's what some say about new copyright legislation working its way through the European Parliament in Brussels. But behind all the talk about censorship machines and the death of memes is another much more fundamental issue -- the power of big tech companies.

The copyright legislation was designed to update European copyright law to reflect the challenges of a digital world.

Indeed, the debate around the European copyright directive is really about who profits from what is circulated on the internet. Should it be the big platform companies like Google and Facebook that have created new ways of distributing content and built up gigantic advertising business in the process? Or should it be "legacy" media firms like newspapers and TV networks that still create a lot of content?

Three parts of the regulation have proved controversial.

Article 3 would limit companies' ability to data-mine texts. Research organizations could use algorithms to mine texts, but in some cases firms would need a license to do the same thing.

Article 11 of the directive would require content-aggregation sites to pay content owners for the headlines they use to link to an original article on another site. For instance, Google News would need to pay The Guardian for using a headline that links through to an article on The Guardian's website.

Article 13 of the directive puts the onus on large tech firms to get the agreement of copyright holders when sharing content on their sites. For instance, Facebook would have to make sure an image shared by a user is not under copyright.

The new legislation has sparked outcries in the tech community. In an open letter to the European Parliament, 70 public figures, including Tim Berners-Lee (inventor of the World Wide Web) , warned that it could transform "the Internet from an open platform for sharing and innovation, into a tool for the automated surveillance and control of its users."

Intellectual property rights experts also claimed that changes to the legislation will create more problems than they solve.

Some corners of the internet have been flooded with talk about "memes bans," "link taxes" and "censorship machines." Opponents of the directive have pointed out the role of "legacy" media outfits, like the German media conglomerate Alex Springer, in promoting the law.

Behind the outrage is the tale of big tech companies confronting legislative changes that are a fundamental challenge to their business model. And, to avoid having to transform it, the companies are trying to use significant political power.

Each of the changes in European legislation create a big problem for those business models. Article 3 would put the brakes on big business opportunities for these companies in text mining and artificial intelligence. Article 11 represents an attack on the huge business big tech firms have built by selling advertising placed next to content others have produced. Article 13 would make it much harder for big tech firms to benefit from content produced by others while not having to pay those who produced it.

The new legislation could mean lower growth opportunities, more cost and less profit for these big tech companies. According to one estimate, Google has spent about 31 million euros lobbying Europe in recent years.

This has been both through direct lobbying (which it spent over 5 million euros on in 2016 alone), as well as indirect lobbying undertaken by the 24 lobbying organizations in Brussels it regularly funds. Bureaucrats working in the European Commission have declared the amount of lobbying from both sides of the argument "astonishing."

There is a big chance that as big tech battles it out with legacy media in a lobby war in Brussels, the one group that will lose out are the people who actually create the photos, songs and texts we share every day, and are unrewarded. What about them?

urn:contentItem:5XK0-8N61-F03R-N0H6-00000-00Why you need to teach your kids about data privacy2019-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:08ZLexisNexisWhy you need to teach your kids about data privacyThe Conversation

Nov 23, 2019( TheNextWeb.com: http://thenextweb.com Delivered by Newstex) Google recently agreed to pay a US$170 million fine for illegally gathering children's personal data on YouTube without parental consent[1], which is a violation under the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)[2]. The United States Federal Trade Commission and the New York State Attorney General — who together brought the case against Google — now require YouTube to obtain consent from parents before collecting or sharing personal information. In addition, creators of child-directed content must self-identify to restrict the delivery of targeted ads. The $170 million fine is a pittance given Alphabet Inc.'s (Google's holding company) valuation of more than US$700 billion[3]. [embedded content] Our digital identities comprise data collected across our activities, making personal identifying information irrelevant. Children today are subjugated to a scale of data collection and targeting that we cannot fathom.

Right now, we also have no clue about the consequences, and regulatory protections to data-proof their futures are far from certain. My ongoing research on how big tech and media conglomerates are using dark pattern design to bypass privacy regulations protecting personal information has revealed how vulnerable children are to data collection and how Canada's legislation in particular is failing them.Incomprehensible scaleFor adults and children, Google has access to everything from search queries to online purchases to any app and website associated with gmail accounts —including deleted accounts[4]— or linked via cross-browser finger-printing[5]. As a parent, you create a network of cross-connections when you input information to make purchases for your child online or set up accounts for your child on apps and websites. Added to this is all your child's activity on YouTube and YouTube Kids, search data to clicks on recommended videos to rewinds and duration of play time. Then add cross-browser fingerprinting and most recently, Google's 'GDPR workaround,' secret buried web tracking pages that act as pseudonymous markers[6] that track user activity across the web. This latter violation of data privacy was revealed in a complaint to the Irish Data Protection Commission[7] filed the same day Google's fine was made public. We are talking about vast fields of aggregate data, the scale of which is difficult to comprehend; this data can be parsed by the artificial intelligence recommendation algorithms that Google has pioneered, and that now steer everything from employment application processes[8] to dating apps[9]. Children in the United States and Canada have another significant, persistent arena where information is being produced by them and collected by Google. Google entered the educational sphere in 2012, and now dominates educational technology market in the U.S., giving Google unprecedented parent-sanctioned access to children's data through kindergarten to Grade 12[10].https://images.theconversation.com/files/293673/original/file-20190923-54749-11uq082.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0...5...o=format...000...=cliphttps://thenextweb.com/syndication/2019/11/23/why-you-need-to-teach-your-kids-about-data-privacy/#The growing presence in classrooms of computers, devices and the internet raises concerns about children's privacy and data collection by large corporations like Google. ShutterstockDominance in the educational sphereAlphabet Inc. dominates child-directed and child-featured content online through YouTube Kids and has now colonized online educational spaces through Google Docs, G-Suite, Chromebooks and the associated Gmail accounts for children that are required for use[11]. This means that Google's access to children's data spans entertainment (YouTube and YouTube Kids), search and purchase histories (via associated parental accounts), and educational sectors. The uptake numbers in the educational technology sphere are staggering. Between 2012 and 2016, Google Chromebooks went from less than one percent of the U.S. school market to over 50 percent — more than 30 million Chromebooks are currently being used in American classrooms. By 2017, more than 58 percent of devices purchased for U.S. schools were Google devices[12]; more than 80 million instructors and children use them globally[13]. Given Google's history of privacy violations[14], it's no surprise that Google's rollout of Chromebooks again violated children's data privacy. Initially, Google resisted complying with the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)[15], providing links to its security policies, which FERPA rejected. In 2015, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) filed an FTC complaint[16] because Chromebook default settings initially allowed Google to collect user data including 'Web browsing histories, search-engine results, YouTube viewing habits and saved passwords.' Harry Brignull, a user experience specialist, coined the term 'dark pattern' to describe a 'user interface that has been carefully crafted to trick users into doing things, such as buying insurance with their purchase or signing up for recurring bills[17].' Gmail accounts for children remain a standard practice in schools today. Standard practice continues to be that children are enrolled by schools en masse into Gmail accounts[18], often without parental consent, using their full names, and 'into other services that collect data without any notification.' This data collection is presented as benign, optimizing your child's experience, enriching education, democratizing access to 21st century online resources.Updating the lawsWhat Google has done is to create a dynamic, adaptive system of data collection that has already colonized our children's futures, given what we now know of how ad targeting can manipulate behavior[19]. We have no way of knowing how this depth of data collection may be used in years to come. In March 2019, U.S. senators Ed Markey and Josh Hawley introduced a bipartisan bill to update COPPA[20], banning targeting ads to children, extending privacy protections to 13- to 15-year-olds so data cannot be collected without user permission and an 'eraser button' that would allow parents and kids to delete personal information. This proposed update to COPPA is crucial legislation that Canadians should be studying - in addition to the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation[21] - as again, there are multiple documented instances of Alphabet's subsidiaries failing to protect children's privacy. This legislation, if passed, would have enormous impact on the revenue of the digital ad market for Google and Facebook, as digital ad revenue in the U.S. totaled $107 billion in 2018[22] We should anticipate sustained resistance from Alphabet's subsidiary companies and the other major platforms. A focus on how we can ensure the consistent protection of the data privacy of children and youth must be central to our discussions of technology globally and to Justin Trudeau's proposed Digital Charter[23] nationally in Canada.
